The intensification of production in the poultry industry causes the generation and accumulation of solid waste. Efforts are being made to reduce the pollutant load of these materials by using them as a productive input. In this sense, the development of catalysts is an alternative. In this work, powdered and monolithic cobalt and calcium catalysts were synthesized using waste eggshells by means of a simple, environmentally friendly, and low-cost method. The catalysts were tested in the toluene oxidation reaction. The best catalytic performance was obtained with a catalyst prepared with Co (16 wt%) on eggshell calcined at 450 ºC (CoC-450). The combination and interaction between Co and Ca species and the highest Co/Ca and Olatt/Oads surface ratios improved the adsorption and activation of toluene. For application under real conditions, a structured catalytic material M-CoC-450 was developed, which reached 100% conversion at 260 °C. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Hydrocarbon catalytic oxidation Waste reuse Environmental pollution Green material and sustainability Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction One of the methods used in recent years to reduce the existing environmental damage throughout the planet is the correct management of waste. In this sense, reuse is the most sustainable process to obtain new materials from waste treatment and, therefore, it is of great importance to achieve the development of technologies that take advantage of waste as a resource [1–3]. Eggs are a staple food that is consumed all over the world, both in homes and at an industrial level since, due to their properties, they constitute a fundamental product in the food sector. The shell represents around 10 wt% of the egg, so large quantities of this waste are generated in egg-producing industries, which are normally discarded without any prior treatment. Specifically, according to data from the FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations), approximately 8.5 million tons of chicken eggshells are generated worldwide each year (FAO, 2021) [4]. For this reason, it is extremely important to study the possible uses of this material. For example, as an alternative source of CaCO3 to reduce the impact on natural reserves of limestone, a non-renewable natural source [5,6]. A large number of recent studies show the various applications for which eggshell has been studied including the production of feed supplements for livestock [7], source of calcium for food fortification [8], functional biomaterials [9], construction materials [10,11], soil conditioning and remediation [12,13], air and water pollution control and wastewater treatment [14]. Besides, eggshell can act as an electrode [15], as a biodiesel catalyst [16], for the production of heterogeneous catalysts used in synthesis of hydrogen [14], synthesis of dimethyl carbonate [17], hydrocarbon oxidation [18] and also as a CO2 adsorbent [19]. Chicken eggshell is made up of 94 wt% calcium carbonate, 1 wt% magnesium carbonate, 1 wt% calcium phosphate, organic materials (mainly protein), and water, making it a great source of CaCO3 [20,21]. This material can be used directly or can be converted to CaO by heat treatment. Both materials, CaCO3 and CaO, can be used as a support for active materials employed in various catalytic processes [6]. Catalytic processes are applied to reduce air pollution which represents a threat to human health and the environment. The main polluting gases are nitrogen oxides (NO, NO2), sulfur oxides (SO2), carbon oxides (CO, CO2), volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and main unburned hydrocarbons (HCs) which come from power generation plants, from chemical and petrochemical industries as well as those produced by different means of transport [22,23]. Unburned hydrocarbons include a large number of chemical species (aromatic compounds, paraffin, olefins, etc.) that are toxic to health and are also the main source of photochemical reactions in the atmosphere, producing various environmental risks. Some of the processes used are catalytic reduction, catalytic oxidation, and adsorption processes, among others [24,25]. Catalytic oxidation is one of the most promising and environmentally friendly control technologies. It is also considered to be one of the most effective and economically viable. Due to the use of catalysts, catalytic oxidation requires lower temperatures (around 250–500 °C) than conventional thermal oxidation, which is carried out at high operating temperatures (650–1100 °C) [26]. Among the materials studied in catalytic oxidation processes, metal oxides and noble metals are widely used. Among transition metals, cobalt is one of the most promising ones for the oxidation of hydrocarbons. Cobalt oxides have very good activity and represent a low-cost, relatively non-toxic alternative that has been successfully used [27,28], mainly the spinel Co3O4, which exhibits redox chemical properties [29]. On the other hand, the design and development of these catalysts requires taking into account a series of factors in addition to high activity, selectivity and useful life. It is necessary to minimize the alteration of the operating conditions of the catalytic process, the pressure drop being an important factor that must be as low as possible [30]. Structured catalysts are used to reach this objective [31]. In this work, powder and monolithic cobalt catalysts were developed using waste eggshell as a support. They were synthesized by a simple, environmentally friendly and low-cost method. The catalytic materials were tested in the hydrocarbon oxidation reaction using toluene as a probe molecule. The influence of the variation in the calcination temperature of the catalysts on its catalytic performance was studied. On the other hand, the effect of the presence of H2O and CO2 in the feed stream on the catalytic stability was analyzed. In order to study the composition and nature of the active sites, the materials were characterized by different techniques such as thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature programmed reduction (TPR), infrared (FTIR), Raman and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). 2 Experimental 2.1 Powder catalysts preparation The preparation of the catalysts from chicken eggshells, whose composition is high in calcium carbonate, requires a series of steps that are described below. First, the testaceous membrane present in the inner part of the eggshell was removed. Then, it was immersed in distilled water and placed in an ultrasonic bath to remove remaining impurities. Finally, it was dried in an oven at 100 °C for 1 h. The dried shells were ground and sieved to get a uniform particle size of approximately 180 µm. This sample was named (C). Cobalt addition was performed by the wet impregnation method, using an aqueous solution of cobalt acetate. For this procedure, 50 mL of the cobalt solution 0.1 M were added to 2 g of the shell (C) and the suspension was stirred for 12 h at room temperature. Then, the temperature was increased to 80 °C and the water was evaporated under continuous stirred agitation. Finally, the sample was oven dried at 100 °C for 4 h. It was denoted CoC. The CoC sample was calcined in a muffle at 2 ºCmin−1 during 8 h at different temperatures (450 °C, 550 °C, 700 °C, and 900 °C) to generate four different samples: CoC-450, CoC-550, CoC-700, and CoC-900. The powdered eggshell was also calcined at 450 °C (C-450) and 900 °C (C-900). On the other hand, two samples used as references were prepared: a cobalt catalyst using low surface area silica was prepared by wet impregnation and calcined at 450 ºC (CoSilica-450); the other catalyst was prepared by mechanical mixing between Co3O4 and eggshell calcined at 450 °C (Co-C-450). In both samples, the cobalt concentration was 16 wt%. 2.2 Structured catalyst preparation Honeycomb monoliths made of cordierite (2MgO-5SiO2-2Al2O3) were used as substrate. The preparation was based on the deposition of powder catalyst CoC onto cordierite honeycomb monoliths (dimensions 1 cm x 1 cm and 2 cm) by the washcoating method. An aqueous suspension was prepared with 20 wt% of catalyst (CoC), adding 1 wt% colloidal silica to improve the catalytic film adherence to the walls of structured support [30]. The monoliths were immersed in the suspension, and the excess in the channels was removed by blowing; then, they were dried in an oven for 1 h at 100 °C, and weighed to control the gains. The process was repeated until a specific catalyst loading of approximately 200 mg was achieved. Finally, the samples were calcined at 450 °C for 8 h (M-CoC-450). 2.3 Physicochemical characterization The calcium and cobalt content of the samples calcined at different temperatures was determined by means of inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES Optima 2100 DV, Perkin Elmer). The textural properties were determined by N2 adsorption at − 196 ºC. The calcined samples were previously treated in inert atmosphere at 200 ºC. For the measurements, a Quantachrome Autosorb sortometer was used. The specific surface areas were estimated using the Brunauer, Emmett and Teller (BET) model. The surface morphology, microstructure, and dispersion of the catalysts were studied using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The analyses were performed using a PhenomProX microscope with a fully integrated EDS detector and software. To analyze the decomposition temperature of the materials, a thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed The thermograms were obtained on a Mettler Toledo Star, TGA/SDTA 851. An amount of 15 mg of material was loaded into an alumina crucible of 70 µL. The experiment was carried out at a temperature range of 25–900 °C at a rate of 10 °Cmin−1 under a stream of 40 cm3min−1 of air. Mass loss as a function of temperature was recorded. The analysis of the crystalline phases of powder materials calcined at different temperatures and monoliths was performed by X-ray diffraction (XRD). The samples were measured in a PANalytical XRD equipment, with CuKα radiation, a voltage of 40 kV, and a current of 45 mA. The analysis range was from 5° to 80° and the scanning speed was 2°min−1. The reducibility of the samples components and their interaction were studied by means of temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR). The characterization was carried out using a 5% H2 in Ar stream. The heating ramp was 10 °C min−1 from 50 °C to 900 °C for all the samples. Before reduction, the sample was heated in inert gas up to 200 °C. Calcined eggshell and catalysts were studied by means of FTIR spectroscopy. The spectra were obtained with a Shimadzu 8101 M, IR Prestige-21, equipped with a high sensitivity DLATGS detector. The measurements were carried out with self-supported samples with a diameter of 1.3 cm after dilution in KBr. Absorption spectra were obtained with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and 80 scans. In addition, laser Raman spectroscopy was employed. The spectra of the catalysts were recorded using a Horiba Jobin YVON Lab RAM HR spectrometer coupled to an Olympus confocal microscope and equipped with a CCD detector at 200 K. The excitation source was an Ar ion laser, wavelength 514.5 nm, and power 30 mW. The oxidation state and the relative concentration of the elements present on the surface of the catalysts were analyzed by means of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS analysis was performed in a multi-technique system (SPECS) equipped with a dual Ag/Al monochromatic X-ray source and a PHOIBOS 150 hemispherical analyzer. The spectra were obtained with monochromatic Al Kα radiation at 300 W. The pass energy used was 30 eV and the transmission mode of the analyzer was fixed (FAT). The samples were pressed, supported on sample holders of the instrument, and evacuated at 10−2 mbar for 10 min at 200 °C in the pretreatment chamber of the instrument. Then the samples were evacuated under ultra-high vacuum in the measurement chamber for at least two hours before measurements. The pressure during the measurement was of less than 2.10−9 mbar. The adhesion of the catalytic layer to the cordierite monolith was analyzed by means of a mechanical stability test. The test was performed with the previously calcined structured catalyst. The monolithic catalyst was immersed in acetone inside a glass vessel that was placed in an ultrasonic bath for 5 min (Cole Parmer, 47 kHz, and 130 W). The sample was dried in an oven at 120 °C for 1 h. The sequence was repeated several times until the weight remained stable. The weight was measured after and before each cycle. Optical micrographs were taken with a Leica S8 APO optical microscope equipped with a Leica LC3 digital camera and LAS EZ software was used to image the monoliths. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation The catalytic oxidation of toluene was used as a test reaction to evaluate the performance of the prepared catalysts. A flow system coupled to a gas chromatograph, GC-2014 SHIMADZU, equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used for this purpose. A Bentone packed column (Sigma Aldrich) was used to separate toluene from the other reactants and products. The reaction was carried out with a toluene concentration of 1000 ppm diluted in helium, in excess of oxygen (10%), a space velocity of 20000 h−1, and a temperature range from 150 °C to 550 °C. In addition, the catalyst with the best performance was selected and the effect of the addition of 2% water and 10% CO2 in the feed stream was analyzed for a total time of 35 h. Toluene conversion was calculated as follows: X Tol = ( C in − C out ) C in * 100 CO 2 selectivity = CO 2 out 7 * ( C in − C out ) * 100 where: C in = toluene concentration at inlet C out = toluene concentration at the outlet CO 2 out = CO 2 concentration at the oulet 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Powder catalysts The cobalt and calcium contents of eggshell and catalysts were determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES). The results are shown in Table 1. It was observed that the cobalt and calcium concentration increased at higher calcination temperatures. This could be due to the decomposition of calcium carbonate, which occurs at high temperatures. The specific surface area of eggshell and catalysts calcined at different temperatures was studied by N2 adsorption. The analysis of the textural properties shows that all the materials were non-porous with a specific surface area of less than 10 m2g−1 [32]. The isotherms of all the samples were of type II, according to the IUPAC classification. The low surface area values are typical of these materials [19,33]. According to the SEM images and elemental mapping results of the four catalysts ( Fig. 1), cobalt was highly and homogeneously distributed over the entire surface. Moreover, no agglomerate formation was observed. The eggshell sample (C) and the CoC catalyst were studied by thermogravimetric analysis. The thermograms are shown in Fig. 2. The TG curve belonging to eggshell registered in air flow presented a slight mass loss between 150 and 200 °C corresponding to the decomposition of adsorbed water and residual organic matter. In addition, a considerable loss of mass between 650 and 800 °C was observed, which would correspond to the decomposition of calcium carbonate into calcium oxide and carbon dioxide (Eq. 1) [19]. The TG curve of the CoC obtained with air flow is also shown in this figure. A first stage of mass loss was observed between 45 and 200 °C, which could be attributed to the dehydration of the tetrahydrate cobalt acetate to produce the anhydrous salt (Eq. 2). [34–36]. Between 200 and 400 °C, a sharp drop was observed which would be due to the decomposition of the cobalt acetate into Co3O4 [37]. Finally, a loss of mass was observed between 600 and 800 °C, which could be associated with the decomposition of calcium carbonate and the possible formation of oxides. (1) CaCO 3 ↔ CaO + CO 2 (2) Co ( CH 3 COO ) 2 . 4 H 2 O → Co ( CH 3 COO ) 2 + 4 H 2 O In order to determine the phases present in the materials, the samples calcined at different temperatures were studied by XRD. Fig. 3A shows the diffractograms (a-c) of the uncalcined (C) and calcined eggshells at 450 °C (C-450) and 900 °C (C-900). The main sharp signals at 2Ѳ = 22.9; 29.3; 35.8; 43.1; 47.3 and 48.5° observed in pattern (a), uncalcined eggshell (C), are characteristic of crystalline structure and correspond to the diffraction peaks associated with CaCO3 [38]. On the other hand, these same signals were present in the eggshell calcined at 450 °C (C-450). This would indicate that the material is stable, maintaining the same crystalline structure and phase. A similar diffraction pattern was detected in the diffractogram of the eggshell calcined at 550 ºC. However, in pattern (c), eggshell calcined at 900 °C, a significant change was observed. In this case, the diffractogram showed the characteristic peaks of CaO formed during calcination at 900 °C, product of the thermal decomposition of calcium carbonate [19,33,38–40]. The same diffraction pattern (not showed) was observed for the eggshell calcined at 700 ºC. Fig. 3B shows the diffractograms of catalysts CoC-450, CoC-550, CoC-700, and CoC-900. These diffraction patterns are more complex because signals from different calcium and cobalt crystalline phases appear according to different calcination temperatures. The catalytic materials calcined at 450 °C and 550 °C (patterns (d) and (e), respectively), presented characteristic CaCO3 signals and, on the other hand, signals corresponding to the Co3O4 (2Ѳ =31.3; 36.8; 38.5; 44.8; 59.3; 65.2). [28,41–43]. When increasing the calcination temperature to 700 °C (CoC-700), in addition to the CaCO3 signals, CaO signals were also evidenced as a result of the partial decomposition of calcium carbonate into oxide. In addition, Ca(OH)2 signals resulting from the hydration of CaO in contact with ambient humidity were observed (Fig. 3B (f)). It should be noted that the characteristic diffraction peaks of cobalt spinel (Co3O4) were not detected. However, this material presented signals that could be attributed to the formation of a mixed calcium and cobalt oxide Ca3Co4O9 [44,45]. By further increasing the calcination temperature up to 900 °C, the diffractogram of CoC-900 (pattern (g)) showed characteristic CaO peaks and signals due to the formation of a mixed oxide Ca3Co2O6 [46,47]. There are several publications in which these mixed oxides of calcium and cobalt were synthesized by different methods and characterized. Sotelo et al. [45] studied the effect of three synthesis methods, i.e., coprecipitation with ammonium carbonate, oxalic acid, and attrition milling, on the Ca3Co4O9 thermoelectric ceramic performances and compared with the classical solid state route. They found that by the coprecipitation method they were able to obtain the pure Ca3Co4O9 phase, while attrition milling and classical solid state produced small amounts of Ca3Co2O6 as secondary phase. Yu et al. [46] synthesized Ca3Co2O6 (CCO) by the conventional solid state reaction using CaCO3 and Co3O4 powders. CCO was calcined at different temperatures 900, 950 and 1000 ºC. They observed that impurity phases were present in the powders calcined at 900 and 1000 ºC, while at 950 ºC they were able to obtain a single phase structure. In order to deepen the characterization of cobalt species and their interaction with calcium in CoC catalysts calcined at different temperatures, studies by temperature programmed reduction (H2 –TPR) were carried out. Fig. 4 shows the reduction profiles of the four CoC catalysts and C-450 (profile a) together with two reference samples, CoSilica-450 (profile b) and Co-C-450 (profile c), which were also studied to ascertain the interaction between calcium and cobalt species. The profile (d), corresponding to CoC-450 presented reduction peaks in two temperature regions. At low temperatures, between 200 and 450 °C, two reduction peaks were observed at 279 and 357 °C, corresponding to the reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ and Co2+ to Co0 species, respectively belonging to Co3O4 [48,49]. Meanwhile, at higher temperatures, between 500 and 700 °C the reduction of cobalt species would be completed and simultaneously the decomposition of calcium carbonate into CO2 would occur [50]. In this vein, eggshell calcined at 450 ºC, C-450, (profile a) showed a single wide reduction signal centered at 746 ºC, which was attributed to the decomposition of calcium carbonate. On the other hand, CoSilica-450 (cobalt supported on inert silica, prepared by wet impregnation and calcined at 450 ºC) showed an asymmetric reduction peak, with a maximum at 330 ºC and a shoulder at around 290 ºC. This profile is characteristic of Co3O4 total reduction. Moreover, when Co-C-450 (sample prepared by mechanical mixing of Co3O4 and C-450) was analyzed, a different profile was obtained. In the temperature region below 400 ºC, the characteristic reduction of Co3O4 is observed, while in the region between 400 and 700 ºC, a broad peak could be attributed to the decomposition of calcium carbonate. It is possible that the presence of metallic cobalt produced at low temperatures promotes the decomposition of calcium carbonate by shifting the peak to lower temperatures. This shift occurs at even lower temperatures than those observed for CoC-450. This could be due to the fact that Co3O4 and CaCO3 in Co-C-450, prepared by mechanical mixing, present a weak interaction, so the carbonate is less impeded to decompose compared to the CoC-450 catalyst, in which there is a stronger cobalt-calcium interaction. In summary, the reduction profile of CoC-450 (profile d) would indicate that during the synthesis by wet impregnation and subsequent calcination, a higher interaction between calcium and cobalt species is generated. This interaction provokes a slight shift to higher reduction temperatures of Co3+/Co2+ species while decreasing the decomposition temperature of calcium carbonate. Furthermore, from the XRD results it is clear that the calcination temperature had a strong influence on the formation of the different phases. When the reduction profile of the catalyst calcined at 550 °C (profile e) was analyzed, a shift towards higher reduction temperatures was observed in the low temperature region compared to CoC-450 profile, while at temperatures between 500 and 700 °C it presented a similar behavior. In the case of CoC-700 and CoC-900 catalysts, where the formation of mixed oxides was observed, the reduction profiles changed significantly. The cobalt reduction peaks shifted to even higher temperatures. This could be due to the interaction between calcium and cobalt forming the mixed oxides. According to these results, the reduction of cobalt would be complete [51,52]. As could be seen in the figure, although all CoC catalysts contain similar cobalt loading, the profiles changed with increasing calcination temperature. This is related to the different calcium and cobalt species present in these catalysts. The molar ratios H2/Co calculated for all CoC catalyst are shown in Table 1. The FTIR spectra registered for calcined and non-calcined eggshell and different catalysts are shown in Fig. 5. The qualitative analysis of the characteristic vibrational wavenumbers provides information on the chemical constituents of the compounds. Fig. 5A presents the spectra of the uncalcined shell, (C), and calcined eggshell, C-450 and C-900. In spectrum (a), corresponding to the uncalcined shell, six bands were detected. In the spectrum a broad band at 3428 cm−1 corresponding to the stretching vibration of the OH- groups of the adsorbed residual water was observed. This water could be interacting with the carbonate groups present causing the formation of (HCO3)- species, whose vibration is evident at 2514 cm−1. The signal at 1798 cm−1 probably belongs to the CO bonds of the carbonate; the 1438 cm−1 signal is assigned to the C-O asymmetric stretching mode, and the sharp and intense peaks observed at 711 and 873 cm−1 represent C-O stretching and bending modes of CaCO3 and OCO out-of-plane vibrational mode, respectively. In addition, spectrum (b) presented the same signals. The same spectrum was observed for the eggshell calcined at 550 ºC. However, spectrum (c) showed the appearance of a broad band around 500 cm−1 that can be assigned to the vibration of the Ca-O bond of CaO and a sharp band at 3647 cm−1 corresponding to OH- groups of Ca(OH)2 formed by the adsorption of water on the CaO [39,40,53]. A similar spectrum was observed for the eggshell calcined at 700 ºC. Fig. 5B shows the spectra of all catalysts, CoC-450, CoC-550, CoC-700, and CoC-900. Bands belonging to the region 4000–700 cm−1 corresponding to carbonate and OH- species were also present in the cobalt-based catalysts. On the other hand, in spectra (d) and (e), corresponding to samples CoC-450 and CoC-550, two new signals, 567 cm−1 and 664 cm−1, were observed, which can be assigned to the vibration of the Co-O bond of the Co3O4 spinel. Finally, spectra (f) and (g) corresponding to materials CoC-700 and CoC-900, presented bands around 550 cm−1 that could be assigned to the Ca-O and Co-O bonds belonging to the mixed oxides of cobalt and calcium [19,54]. These results are consistent with those obtained by XRD. The Raman spectra of four different catalytic materials, CoC-450, CoC-550, CoC-700, and CoC-900, are presented in Fig. 6. The spectra (a) and (b) indicate that CoC-450 and CoC-550, which were calcined at lower temperatures, exhibit the main characteristic Raman band of Co3O4 spinel, at 483, 529, and 695 cm−1 [43,55,56]. No signals associated with calcium species were detected in these samples. On the other hand, the Raman spectrum of CoC-700 reveals a signal at 289 cm−1, while the spectrum of CoC-900 shows two signals at 573 and 639 cm−1, which are attributed to the mixed oxides which were identified by XRD [57,58]. The surface composition and oxidation state of the species were studied by XPS. Fig. 7 exhibits the Co 2p spectra of the four CoC catalysts. They show two main peaks centered at 780 eV (Co 2p3/2) and 795 eV (Co 2p1/2) with a spin-orbital splitting close to 15 eV, indicating the presence of the Co2+ and Co3+ mixture [59]. In addition, all samples show a satellite peak corresponding to Co2+ at higher binding energies than the main peaks [60]. In this region, Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 main peaks were adjusted with two components. The binding energies of the two contributions to the Co2p3/2 region are shown in Table 2. For the Co 2p3/2 region, several authors have assigned the component at around 779 eV to Co3+ species, while the signal at slightly higher binding energy (∼780.2 eV) to Co2+ species [61–64]. When the Ca 2p region was studied (Fig. 1S), two peaks centered around 346 eV and 349 eV corresponding to Ca 2p3/2 and Ca 2p1/2 respectively, were observed in the four catalysts. The peaks were assigned to Ca2+ belonging to CaCO3. Although CaCO3 signals were not detected by XRD in the material calcined at temperatures of 900 °C, these signals were observed when studied by IR. It is known that the CaO present in these samples hydrates and carbonates in contact with the atmosphere [65,66]. Moreover, the presence of Ca2+ species from Ca(OH)2, which present binding energy values similar to those reported for Ca2+ from CaO and CaCO3, cannot be discarded [67–69]. On the other hand, by analyzing the surface molar ratio Co/Ca shown (Table 2) for the different catalysts, it could be observed that the concentration of cobalt exposed on the surface decreased considerably as the calcination temperature increased. If compared to the bulk molar ratio, Co/Ca, which was 0.39, it could be thought that at low calcination temperatures (450 and 550 °C), cobalt species are concentrated in the catalyst surface, while at higher calcination temperature (700 and 900 °C) exists a migration of cobalt species to the sinus of the catalyst, possibly due to the formation of mixed oxides. The O 1 s region was also analyzed using XPS. In this region, two peaks were observed in the spectra of the four catalysts (Fig. S2). The first peak, centered at approximately 529 eV was attributed to lattice oxygen (Olatt). The second peak, located at higher binding energy, around 531 eV, was attributed to adsorbed oxygen species (Oads) [60,70,71]. According to Fig. S2, it is clear that in the spectra of CoC-450 and CoC-550, the lower binding energy peak (529.1–529.2 eV) is associated to oxygen species belonging to Co3O4 oxide. In the spectra corresponding to the samples calcined at higher temperature, a slightly shift to lower binding energy is detected (528.7 and 528.5 eV for CoC-700 and CoC-900, respectively). This behavior could correspond to the formation of mixed oxides, which were observed by XRD. On the other hand, the peak at higher binding energy (around 531 eV) might correspond to the overlapping of different adsorbed oxygen species. Analyzing the O1s signals, the Olatt/Oads ratios were CoC-450 (1.81), CoC-550 (1.75), CoC-700 (1.28) and CoC-900 (1.09), indicating a decrease in the peak associated with the lattice oxygen species as the calcination temperature of the catalysts was increased. The four catalysts (CoC-450, CoC-550, CoC-700 and CoC-900), eggshell (C), eggshell calcined at 450 °C (C-450) and reference materials (CoSilica-450 and Co-C-450) were studied for the oxidation reaction of toluene. Fig. 8 shows the toluene conversion curves as a function of temperature. In the CoC materials the influence of the calcination temperature on the catalytic activity of each sample was analyzed. The CoC-450 catalyst presented its activation temperature, T20% (the temperature at which 20% conversion is reached), at 200 °C and a rapid conversion reaching 90% conversion (T90%) at 260 °C. In turn, the CoC-550 catalyst achieved a T20%= 240 °C quickly reaching a T90%= 290 °C. On the other hand, the materials CoC-700 and CoC-900, presented lower conversion reaching a T90% at 360 °C and 425 °C, respectively. Comparing the performance in toluene oxidation, using T90% as a reference, the four catalysts showed the following order: CoC-450 >CoC-550 >CoC-700 >CoC-900. On the other hand, the results showed that CO2 selectivity was near 100% (Fig. S3). Analyzing the samples without cobalt (C and C-450), it could be observed that both samples reached a low conversion of about 40% at 550 °C. The catalytic activity achieved by these materials could be attributed to the calcium species that constitute the eggshell matrix. In this sense, the calcium could provide the basic active sites on which the hydrocarbons are adsorbed, while the oxygen in the carbonate would contribute to decreasing the activation energy needed to oxidize the toluene [72,73]. Comparing the catalytic behavior of materials with and without cobalt, it was observed that the combination of cobalt and calcium produced a significant improvement in the catalytic activity of all CoC catalysts. As could be observed by XRD and Raman, the different calcination temperatures of the materials generated the formation of different species. At moderate temperatures (450 and 550 ºC) the formation of Co3O4 was observed, while higher calcination temperatures (700 and 900ºC) provoked the formation of mixed oxides. The presence of different cobalt species was directly related to the catalytic activity results reached by these materials. The catalytic oxidation of toluene could be explained by the Mars-Van Krevelen mechanism. In this sense, toluene adsorbs on the catalyst surface and combines with lattice oxygen to produce CO2 and H2O. The consumed lattice oxygen generates vacancies and the metal is reduced. Oxygen from the gas phase replenishes the vacant oxygen while the metal is reoxidized. As it was observed by XPS, the generation of oxygen vacancies facilitated the activation of gas-phase oxygen and the reoxidation of cobalt, where lattice oxygen was the active species. XPS results showed that CoC-450 presented the highest Olatt/Oads ratio. On the other hand, the Co/Ca molar ratio was CoC-450 1.02 > CoC-550 1.01 > CoC-700 0.19 > CoC-900 0.10, where a higher concentration of Co on the surface would imply a greater number of available active sites. These sites would facilitate the adsorption and activation of toluene. In addition, it is known that the toluene oxidation reaction is a redox reaction involving metal species. Therefore, the performance of the catalysts could be related to the reducibility of the species present. The reduction of Co3+ to Co2+ was much easier on the CoC-450 and CoC-550 catalysts than on the CoC-700 and CoC-900 catalysts. In other words, the strong interaction between Co3O4 and eggshell generated a relatively weaker Co-O bond that favored the regeneration of the Co2+ to Co3+ redox cycle. The H2-TPR results showed that the CoC-450 material presented the lowest reduction temperature. Therefore, the CoC-450 catalyst, in which Co3O4 spinel was present, showed the highest Co/Ca surface ratio and Olatt/Oads ratio, and also presented the lowest reduction temperature, which resulted in a better catalytic activity for the oxidation of toluene. In order to analyze the interaction of different species present in the more active catalyst, CoC-450, Fig. 8B shows the comparison between this catalyst and other two catalysts with the same cobalt content (16 wt%). One of them prepared by the same method but, using an inert support (CoSilica-450) and the other, Co-C-450, prepared by a mechanical mix between Co3O4 and calcined eggshell at 450 ºC. The CoC-450 catalyst showed better performance compared to CoSilica-450. This could be attributed to the eggshell structure, where the interaction between cobalt and calcium would favor the oxidation of toluene. The calcium present in the eggshell improves the adsorption of toluene and together with cobalt promotes its activation and oxidation. In turn, the oxygen electron density of calcium carbonate could increase the interaction with the toluene ring, making it more reactive for oxidation [74,75]. On the other hand, CoC-450, prepared by wet impregnation, also showed a better activity than Co-C-450 prepared by mechanical mixing. This could be due to a better contact between calcium and cobalt, achieving a greater interaction, which favors the adsorption and oxidation of toluene. These catalytic results show that the CoC-450 material presented a better activity than the material prepared from a mixture of Co3O4 and eggshell (Co-C-450). This would imply that CoC-450 is an active phase (cobalt) dispersed on the support (eggshell) and not a mixture of oxides. On the other hand, water vapor is present in real reaction conditions, so its influence on the catalyst activity is of outmost importance. For this reason, the incorporation of 2% water into the feed stream was analyzed. The catalytic material with the best performance (CoC-450) was selected and the reaction was studied under the same conditions, at 250 ºC, in reaction cycles of 5 h, for a total time of 35 h. The results showed that there was practically no effect on the catalytic activity, indicating that the catalyst presented resistance to water ( Fig. 9A). On the other hand, the incorporation of 10% CO2 was analyzed and the results are shown in Fig. 9B. The catalytic performance decreased by approximately 5% after introducing CO2. However, the toluene conversion recovered to the original value after cutting CO2 in all cycles. This could be due to the competition between CO2 and toluene for adsorption sites. For this reason, when the CO2 supply was cut off, the conversion recovered since all the sites would be available for the adsorption and subsequent reaction of toluene [76,77]. The development of unconventional reactors is important to optimize mass and energy transfer processes and monolithic catalysts could be a good option. This type of structure provokes a lower pressure drop, diminishes diffusion resistance, and enhances mass and heat transfer more than powder catalysts. 3.2 Monolithic catalyst prepared by CoC-450 Fig. 10 A, B, C and D show the photographs obtained by optical microscopy in which the dimensions of the channels and the thickness of the walls (Fig. 10 A and B) of the monoliths can be appreciated. They show the uniform distribution of the catalyst on the structured support (Fig. 10 C and D) where the formation of agglomerates in the structure was not generated, which is positive since the gas flow through the channels is not modified. Considering that the best performing powder catalyst was the one calcined at 450 ºC, the structured catalyst was calcined at the same temperature and evaluated in reaction under the same conditions presenting a similar catalytic activity ( Fig. 11 A). Fig. 11 B shows the stability results of the catalytic film on the monolith, M-CoC-450. In the first two sonication cycles a mass loss of approximately 3 wt% is observed, which in the following cycles tends to stabilize. After 17 cycles under the sonication process, it was observed that 96.4% of the active mass remained adhered to the cordierite walls of the monolith. Fig. 11 C shows the XRD diffractogram of the structured catalyst, M-CoC-450, where the same signals presented by the powdered catalytic material, both CaCO3 and cobalt spinel, Co3O4, could be observed. In addition, the appearance of new diffraction peaks corresponding to the cordierite phases was observed [78,79]. This would indicate that the catalyst does not undergo any structural alteration when deposited on the structured support, nor would an interaction with the monolithic support occur. 4 Conclusions The results obtained in this work indicated that it was possible to use waste eggshells as a support for metal oxide catalysts, obtaining materials by a simple, economical and environmentally friendly methodology. Cobalt and calcium catalysts showed very good results for toluene oxidation. The best catalytic performance was obtained with the CoC-450 catalyst. The formation of Co3O4 in the catalysts calcined at low temperature and the formation of mixed oxides in the materials calcined at higher temperature were determined by XRD and Raman spectroscopy. The catalytic result obtained by different catalysts are related to the different phases present in these materials. As it could be determined, the surface Co/Ca ratio, the Olatt/Oads ratio and the reducibility of the samples were closely related to the catalytic behavior of the materials. On the other hand, the catalytic activity of the CoC-450 material was superior to that of the catalyst supported on inert silica (CoSilica-450) and to that of the catalyst prepared by mechanical mixing (Co-C-450). This is due to the combination of calcium and cobalt. As well as a better contact and interaction between the Ca and Co species generated during the synthesis, favoring the adsorption and oxidation of toluene. When the introduction of H2O in the feed was studied, it was observed that it did not affect the catalytic activity, while CO2 produced a slight decrease in the conversion, which was restored once the supply was cut off. In addition, a structured catalytic material M-CoC-450 was developed, which achieved 100% conversion at 260 °C. This work demonstrates that it is possible to use waste such as eggshells to develop catalytic materials with great potential for hydrocarbon removal. coredata.dc:description: The intensification of production in the poultry industry causes the generation and accumulation of solid waste. Efforts are being made to reduce the pollutant load of these materials by using them as a productive input. In this sense, the development of catalysts is an alternative. In this work, powdered and monolithic cobalt and calcium catalysts were synthesized using waste eggshells by means of a simple, environmentally friendly, and low-cost method. The catalysts were tested in the toluene oxidation reaction. The best catalytic performance was obtained with a catalyst prepared with Co (16 wt%) on eggshell calcined at 450 ºC (CoC-450). The combination and interaction between Co and Ca species and the highest Co/Ca and Olatt/Oads surface ratios improved the adsorption and activation of toluene. For application under real conditions, a structured catalytic material M-CoC-450 was developed, which reached 100% conversion at 260 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis and characterization of eggshell-based catalysts for the treatment of gaseous pollutants
